segment.source: Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode
segment.target: Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode

segment.source: Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode
segment.target: Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode

segment.source: Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode
segment.target: Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode

segment.source: Boot into UEFI mode or legacy BIOS-compatibility mode when installing Windows from your USB, DVD, or network location.
segment.target: Boot into UEFI mode or legacy BIOS-compatibility mode when installing Windows from your USB, DVD, or network location.

segment.source: If you install Windows using the wrong mode, you won’t be able to use the features of that firmware mode without reformatting the drive.
segment.target: If you install Windows using the wrong mode, you won’t be able to use the features of that firmware mode without reformatting the drive.

segment.source: Select the firmware mode during bootup
segment.target: Select the firmware mode during bootup

segment.source: Boot the PC.
segment.target: Boot the PC.

segment.source: As the firmware starts to run, press the key that opens the boot device menu.
segment.target: As the firmware starts to run, press the key that opens the boot device menu.

segment.source: For example, press the Esc, F2, F9, F12, or other key to enter the firmware or boot menus.
segment.target: For example, press the Esc, F2, F9, F12, or other key to enter the firmware or boot menus.

segment.source: On the boot device menu, select the command that identifies both the firmware mode and the device.
segment.target: On the boot device menu, select the command that identifies both the firmware mode and the device.

segment.source: For example, select UEFI USB Drive or Network - BIOS.
segment.target: For example, select UEFI USB Drive or Network - BIOS.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: You might see separate commands for the same device.
segment.target: You might see separate commands for the same device.

segment.source: For example, you might see UEFI USB Drive and BIOS USB Drive.
segment.target: For example, you might see UEFI USB Drive and BIOS USB Drive.

segment.source: Each command uses the same device and media, but boots the PC in a different firmware mode.
segment.target: Each command uses the same device and media, but boots the PC in a different firmware mode.

segment.source: If a boot device option does not appear for your device:
segment.target: If a boot device option does not appear for your device:

segment.source: Check the options in the firmware menus to enable or disable BIOS-compatibility mode.
segment.target: Check the options in the firmware menus to enable or disable BIOS-compatibility mode.

segment.source: To use BIOS-compatibility mode, check for options in the firmware menus to disable UEFI SecureBoot features.
segment.target: To use BIOS-compatibility mode, check for options in the firmware menus to disable UEFI SecureBoot features.

segment.source: For older PCs (Windows® 7-era or earlier), look for options to Boot from file, and browse to the EFIBOOTBOOTX64.EFI file on that device.
segment.target: For older PCs (Windows® 7-era or earlier), look for options to Boot from file, and browse to the EFIBOOTBOOTX64.EFI file on that device.

segment.source: Use any of these methods to help make sure that Windows is installed using the correct firmware mode
segment.target: Use any of these methods to help make sure that Windows is installed using the correct firmware mode

segment.source: If you install Windows by using Windows Setup or the Windows installation DVD, use preformatted hard drive on your destination PCs.
segment.target: If you install Windows by using Windows Setup or the Windows installation DVD, use preformatted hard drive on your destination PCs.

segment.source: Use the GPT file format for UEFI mode, or the MBR file format for BIOS mode.
segment.target: Use the GPT file format for UEFI mode, or the MBR file format for BIOS mode.

segment.source: When Windows Setup runs, if the PC is booted to the wrong mode, Windows will fail to install.
segment.target: When Windows Setup runs, if the PC is booted to the wrong mode, Windows will fail to install.

segment.source: For more info, see Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style.
segment.target: For more info, see Windows Setup: Installing using the MBR or GPT partition style.

segment.source: You can remove the UEFI or BIOS boot files from either Windows PE or Windows Setup.
segment.target: You can remove the UEFI or BIOS boot files from either Windows PE or Windows Setup.

segment.source: For example, if you only include boot files for UEFI mode on the Windows installation DVD, and during manufacturing you accidentally attempt to boot the PC to BIOS mode, the PC will immediately fail to boot, and you can begin troubleshooting right away.
segment.target: For example, if you only include boot files for UEFI mode on the Windows installation DVD, and during manufacturing you accidentally attempt to boot the PC to BIOS mode, the PC will immediately fail to boot, and you can begin troubleshooting right away.

segment.source: UEFI: To prevent Windows Setup or Windows PE from booting in BIOS mode, remove the bootmgr file on the root of the media.
segment.target: UEFI: To prevent Windows Setup or Windows PE from booting in BIOS mode, remove the bootmgr file on the root of the media.

segment.source: BIOS: To prevent Windows Setup or Windows PE from booting in UEFI mode, remove the efi folder on the root of the media.
segment.target: BIOS: To prevent Windows Setup or Windows PE from booting in UEFI mode, remove the efi folder on the root of the media.

segment.source: From Windows PE, you can check the GetFirmwareEnvironmentVariable function.
segment.target: From Windows PE, you can check the GetFirmwareEnvironmentVariable function.

segment.source: For more info, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more info, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.target: WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive
